column4: description:"Paraldehyde is an acetaldehyde derivative having sedative and anticonvulsant properties and acts by depressing CNS at many levels including reticular activating system."
column10: paraldehyde may cause some unwanted effects. Although not all of these side effects may occur
column11:
if they do occur they may need medical attention.
Check with your doctor as soon as possible if any of the following side effects occur while taking paraldehyde:
More Common:
Coughing
skin rash

column23:

column31: info:"Alcohol can increase the nervous system side effects of paraldehyde such as dizziness
column33: and difficulty concentrating. Some people may also experience impairment in thinking and judgment. You should avoid or limit the use of alcohol while being treated with paraldehyde. Do not use more than the recommended dose of paraldehyde
column34: and avoid activities requiring mental alertness such as driving or operating hazardous machinery until you know how the medication affects you. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions or concerns."

column4: description:"Pentazocine is an opioid pain medication
column5: sometimes called a narcotic.\nPentazocine is used to treat moderate to severe pain in adults and children who are at least 12 years old. It is also used as part of anesthesia for surgery.\nPentazocine may also be used for purposes not listed in this medication guide."

column26: side_effect:"Get emergency medical help if you have signs of an allergic reaction: hives; difficult breathing; swelling of your face
column30: pentazocine can slow your breathing. Death may occur if breathing becomes too weak. A person caring for you should seek emergency medical attention if you have slow breathing with long pauses
column32: or if you are hard to wake up.\nSeek medical attention right away if you have symptoms of serotonin syndrome
column44: or diarrhea.\nSerious side effects may be more likely in older adults and those who are overweight

column4:
description:"
Aceclofenac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with marked anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. 
It is reported to have a higher anti-inflammatory action or at least comparable effects than conventional NSAIDs in double-blind studies .
 Aceclofenac potently inhibits the cyclo-oxygenase enzyme (COX) that is involved in the synthesis of prostaglandins
column5: which are inflammatory mediators that cause pain
column8: and fever.\n It is orally administered for the relief of pain and inflammation in osteoarthritis
column9: rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis. \nAceclofenac belongs to BCS Class II as it possesses poor aqueous solubility. \nIt displays high permeability to penetrate into synovial joints where in patients with osteoarthritis and related conditions
column10: the loss of articular cartilage in the area causes joint pain
column14: and local inflammation . \nAceclofenac is also reported to be effective in other painful conditions such as dental and gynaecological conditions .\n In 1991
column15: aceclofenac was developed as an analog of a commonly prescribed NSAID
column17: via chemical modification in effort to improve the gastrointestinal tolerability of the drug. It is a more commonly prescribed drug in Europe."
column18: absorption:"\nAceclofenac is rapidly and completely absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and circulates mainly as unchanged drug following oral administration.\n Peak plasma concentrations are reached around 1.25 to 3 hours post-ingestion
column19: and the drug penetrates into the synovial fluid where the concentration may reach up to 60% of that in the plasma . \nThere is no accumulation in regular dosing
column20: with similar maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) and time to reach peak plasma concentration (Tmax) after single and multiple doses ."
column21: distribution:"\nThe volume of distribution is approximately 25 L."
column22: metabolism:"\n4'-hydroxyaceclofenac is the main metabolite detected in plasma however other minor metabolites include diclofenac
column25: and 4'-hydroxydiclofenac .\n It is probable that the metabolism of aceclofenac is mediated by CYP2C9 ."
column36: Katare OP: Topical delivery of aceclofenac: challenges and promises of novel drug delivery systems. Biomed Res Int. 2014;2014:406731. doi: 10.1155/2014/406731. Epub 2014 Jun 18. [PubMed:25045671]\n2\u003eLegrand E: Aceclofenac in the management of inflammatory pain. Expert Opin Pharmacother. 2004 Jun;5(6):1347-57. [PubMed:15163279]"
column51: info:"The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Aceclofenac is combined with 16-Bromoepiandrosterone.
column52: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Aceclofenac is combined with 19-norandrostenedione.
column53: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Aceclofenac is combined with 5-androstenedione.
column54: Aceclofenac may increase the anticoagulant activities of Abciximab.
column55: The metabolism of Aceclofenac can be decreased when combined with Abiraterone."

column4:
description:"
Abiraterone is a derivative of steroidal progesterone and is an innovative drug that offers clinical benefit to patients with hormone refractory prostate cancer. 
Abiraterone is administered as an acetate salt prodrug because it has a higher bioavailability and less susceptible to hydrolysis than abiraterone itself. 
FDA approved on April 28
column6: absorption:"\nAbiraterone itself is poorly absorbed and is susceptible to hydrolysis by esterases.\nThe salt form
column8:
is a prodrug which has a much higher oral bioavailability and is also esterase resistant. 
Peak drug concentrations of abiraterone were reached in 1.5 - 4 hours.
Abiraterone acetate was rapidly and completely deacetylated into abiraterone-the parent salt form was not detectable in early pharmacokinetic studies.
Food and high fat meals increases absorption 4.4-fold."
column12: metabolism:"\nAbiraterone acetate is hydrolyzed into active metabolite abiraterone via esterases. CYP3A4 and SULT2A1 further metabolizes abiraterone into two inactive metabolites called abiraterone sulfate and N-oxide abiraterone sulfate."
column25: info:"\nFood and high fat meals increases the drug exposure 4.4-fold. It is suggested that abiraterone is taken on an empty stomach."
column32: info:"The serum concentration of 4-Methoxyamphetamine can be increased when it is combined with Abiraterone.
column33: The metabolism of Aceclofenac can be decreased when combined with Abiraterone.
column34: The serum concentration of Acenocoumarol can be increased when it is combined with Abiraterone.
column35: The serum concentration of Acetaminophen can be increased when it is combined with Abiraterone.
column36: The serum concentration of Acetylcholine can be increased when it is combined with Abiraterone."
